title: Angel
body:
I hung in the dark water like an angel.

My chin above the surface, eyes open, all-seeing, all-knowing. I looked down to the murky depths where my vision failed and for the first time in a long time, it crept over me. The fear of what might be waiting just below.

Something rough wrapped around my ankle, dragging me down. My skin chafed as I desperately tried to pull away. Water rushed into my mouth, burned my throat, filled my lungs.

When I woke from the dream, miles from the lake, the warmth of the single bed did nothing to quell my shivering.

I'd slept early on purpose. I arrived at the forest, dragging the kayak behind me with one hand, the cooler held in the other, the oar tucked under an arm.

As I broke out of the forest to the lake’s shoreline, I glanced around the clearing. The lake was empty tonight, a flat blue mirror in the evening light, surrounded on all sides by ancient woodland. I dumped the cooler on the bank and took out a bottle, swallowing a big gulp of beer. A lovely night, the lake all to myself, but I couldn’t get the nightmare out of my head. The feeling of drowning, of utter hopelessness as the waters closed over me…

I finished the beer. Tonight would not be ruined by a bad dream of all things. This was my time alone, kayaking by starlight. I relished my weekend nights.

I waded out to knee height, pushing the kayak ahead of me, and climbed in. I twirled the oar in one hand, reaching with the other for the red ribbon tied around the handle. As lucky charms go, it was cheaper than a rabbit’s foot.

I paddled a lap round the lake. The kayak sliced through the water, responding to the slightest touch, turning at the lightest lean. In those blissful moments, it was hard to tell where I ended and the boat began.

Evening passed away to true night. The cooler emptied. The final rays playing on the pastel lake faded to sables and greys. The air smelled fresh, like midnight.

I stopped in the middle of the lake. I had the strangest feeling that someone was watching me. I scanned the tree line, but even in broad daylight it would have been hard to tell if anyone was standing there.

Looking down at the dark waters, my insides twisted into a painful nervous ball. No matter how hard I stared, I couldn't see more than an inch below the surface. On any other night I would have laughed it off.

Not far from my kayak, a ripple played over the surface. Too big to be a fish.

I strained my eyes. Stared. The lake stared back. It won.

I called out. No answer. Of course not. There was nobody here. Nobody but me. Was there?

I almost missed the ripple, an inch closer now. There was no denying it anymore. My legs forced into flimsy, hollow plastic, drifting on thousands of litres of dark water, and I was not alone.

The moisture fled from my throat. I couldn't swallow. I couldn't speak. A low moan escaped my lips. An animal keening.

I dropped the oar and paddled with my hands, trying manically to get closer to shore. A rational part of my brain told me to stop, the splashing would only bring it closer. I listened. Froze.

The kayak held me in place, trapped my legs. It felt like a grave. I would have screwed my eyes tight shut if I hadn't forced myself to watch for the ripples, closer and closer.

I looked into the lake and tried to imagine how deep it was.

I prayed to all the gods I'd ever heard of to save me, save me, oh god, please save me.

I saw movement in the murky water.

I had a glimpse of something pale, rapidly rising through the water until-

A torrent of freezing water drenched me. I covered my eyes like a child, hunched and whimpering. If I couldn't see it, it couldn't see me. If I couldn't see it, it couldn't see me.

After long minutes I plucked up the courage to dart my eyes towards it.

It floated beside me, a pale fleshy mound. A hand floated on the water’s surface, a head face down.

I lifted her onto the kayak. Her sodden white frock, ripped and torn. Her pigtails, only one tied with a red ribbon. The ice-cold water must've preserved her almost perfectly. Poor lamb.

I walked my fingers down the soft skin of her leg, until I reached her bare ankle and naked foot. A length of rope had been roughly tied around her ankle; I found the frayed end. Rotting in the lake’s water, it had suddenly snapped. The stone had fallen away, and her body rose like an accusation from the heavens.

Poor, beautiful girl. Her prayers went unanswered. There were plenty more rocks in the lake, and I had all night.
author: TigerHall
